TALK.START.PARA: —What about the new one of Senator Evans? That is even worse.

—That is true. We will have to resort to the freedom of information legislation to get that. That statement by Mr Mahony does not say that the law should be brought into conformity with the direction. All it says is that there is a conflict. Mr Mahony recommends that the conflict be resolved without delay. He did not say whether the law should be brought into conformity with the practice or whether the practice should be brought into conformity with the law. What the Government did was to bring the law into conformity with the practice, namely the practice of the Attorney-General in not enforcing the law. Mr Mahony quoted from the report of the Willett Task Force into allegations about the Customs Service in New South Wales. He said at paragraph 5.73:

SPEECH.PARA: 'The Task Force is of the view that the administrative difficulties caused by the inconsistent policy and treatment of pornography should be remedied by the issue of clear and precise instructions to officers. It is the Task Force's view that the only instruction that could be issued consistently with present legislation is one to the effect that officers should detain any goods coming to their notice which appeared to them to fall within the terms of the regulations, for referral to the Attorney-General's Department.

It can be seen that Labor senators and Labor members of the House of Representatives have been snowed by their Minister in respect of this matter. What the Minister said in the House of Representatives was absolutely false. The charge, and the burden for that, is laid fairly and squarely upon the Minister who gave Mr Duffy that advice. I hope that the Labor members of the House of Representatives and the Senate recognise that they have been snowed by their Ministers. They ought to have a good look at what has occurred and what ought to be done about it, because for the first time people can legally import into this country hard core pornography. As Senator Walters said, according to the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) the barriers to that importation have been lowered. As Mr Barry Taylor said on the Four Corners program:
Private screenings was the first company to actually go out in full colour in the magazines and come out in the open.
The interviewer asked:
But previous to doing that, according to the letter of the law, . . . not what actually happened, but the letter of the law, were you operating illegally?
Taylor said: 'Yes'. The interviewer asked:
Like many other people?
Taylor said:
Now it's legal. In most States.
This is a man who allegedly has a business association with an American with heroin connections. This what he said on Four Corners:
Well I mean this was what we started off as, and as the government-pressure came on the government to turn it into a legal product, we moved in that direction.
How much pressure was put on the government and where did that pressure come from?

TALK.START.PARA: —And at what price?

—I will not go into that, but where did that pressure come from? This Government is supposed to be a government of consensus, yet it rammed through the Senate and rammed through the House of Representatives major changes in the law relating to this material which is, according to the thousands of people who signed the petitions, harmful to society. The Government has not given this Parliament adequate opportunity to examine these matters thoroughly. Indeed, unknown to many of the members of the House of Representatives, the Government brought this matter on in the dead of night, at five minutes to midnight, when all members of the Press had gone to bed and when nobody was listening. The House of Representatives argued it out for an hour and then had one hour of divisions. The Government gagged the debate time and time again. Six times the Government gagged the debate and as many times it voted in relation to motions that were before the Chair. I believe this truly is a matter of public importance. I sincerely hope that the Senate adopts this motion.
—Order! Senator Harradine, your time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a quite extraordinary matter of public importance. It is really nothing more than a third run through of the same debate. I draw honourable senators' attention to the fact that if they want to know what is being said today they can do so by going to Hansard of 4 April as fairly much the same thing is being said by members of the Opposition over and over again. At least they have added a few variations to the substance of the debate in raising this matter of public importance. For instance, they have suggested that we have a precipitate Attorney-General in Senator Gareth Evans. At the same time, on many occasions in this place they have said that the poor Attorney-General is unable to pass any legislation; he is always being forced to put it on the back burner. I ask them and the people of Australia to contemplate how the same argument holds; how the Opposition believes it has an Attorney- General who is bound to put his legislation on the back burner but somehow is able to sneak precipitate pieces of legislation through with nobody looking. I suggest that that part of the Opposition's matter of public importance is a farce.

SPEECH.PARA: Secondly, the Opposition has talked about the problems created by the Federal Government's action. One of the points that I wish to establish today is that the problem is being created by the hype and fearmongering of the Opposition, and its debates and contributions in this place this afternoon are high cases of illustration of that point. The rhetoric and slogans of the Opposition and the continual concern it voices has done nothing by way of education or information for the people of Australia; they simply highlight the concern creating and perpetuating the problem. It is nothing novel. It is the Opposition's perpetual style and it has been highlighted since it became the Opposition.

As I have said, this debate is a third run on this issue in the Parliament this session. As I also have said, if honourable senators want to find out more about it they should go to the Hansard of 4 April of this session and read all about it again. It would seem to be much more useful for the people listening to this debate to be provided with the assurance that the legislation concerning the point of sale control and X-rated videos in association with the total ban on child pornography involving minors under 16, publications that promote, incite or encourage terrorism and those that gratuitously depict extreme cruelty, particularly when combined with sexual element is an important step towards providing just the sort of protection and information that those concerned people have been asking for.

The matter of public importance has been raised as though this concern is something the Opposition has just discovered. That is not true. In fact, this concern has been an issue in the community for a considerable time. The Attorney -General has said that in July last year the Attorneys-General gathered to meet and address this point and discussions have been under way since then. He has made that point and I just reiterate it, but it is clearly too much for the Opposition to understand. It is not a matter of new concern; it is a matter of continuing concern and it is a matter of concern that this Government has addressed with these changes in regulations and legislation.

It was after recent discussions with the Attorneys-General that we had the report that the women's advisers to the Premiers of the States had considered the current proposals for changes in the legislation and found them acceptable. I can assure the Senate that women's advisers do not come to such a decision without much discussion amongst themselves and the women in the women's groups to whom they are responsible and answerable. That is the way that women in such positions operate. Besides, it is a discussion in the women's community and the women's movement broader than just with those women who are in positions to inform government. It is precisely because of the women's concern about pornography that it is an issue of great concern to them. It is not a novel issue and it is certainly not something that has arisen as a result of this legislation. In fact, I reiterate that the women's advisers to the Premiers have appreciated that some of that concern has been addressed by the legislation introduced by this Government.

I return to Senator Walters's contribution-an extraordinary vintage piece of Senator Walters-and just say once again that honourable senators should go back to her speech in Hansard of 4 April earlier this year and they will have almost a rerun. One way in which she added to her speech today was that she drew on evidence from a report in the United Kingdom. However, I would like to draw the Senate's attention to a report on the report. There was an article by Peter Smark in London in the Melbourne Age of 6 April 1984, headed 'UK warning for our video law makers'. The most important part of that article refers to the fact that the research paper put out in Britain had been hastily rushed to the Press, and it states:
This report was rushed into print with maximum speed and resulted in shock and some incredulity.
It goes on, and I think this is very important for the Senate to note:
But the Roman Catholic and Methodist representatives on the group's sponsoring committee withdrew when researchers at Oxford Polytechnic's television research unit claimed Dr Hill-
who produced the report-
had misused their data. Last month, a Catholic official spoke of 'dubious correlation'.

In other words, this evidence has been discredited. I think it is very important to know that the evidence that Senator Walters has been putting and referring to is unreliable. Senator Walters went on to say that she watched the Nationwide program which addressed the problem of video classifications. One of the things that I feel is quite appalling is her claim that every mother would be appalled at that material. I say to Senator Walters, to the people listening to this debate and to the Senate chamber that every reasonable Australian would be appalled. I think it is a disgrace that Senator Walters assumes that only mothers would be appalled at the material. Every reasonable man and woman, married or single, parent or not, would be appalled at the material. That is why most of us are very grateful that we have a classification group which actually performs the task of watching material and providing either an X classification or no classification-that is, rule it out altogether and save us the horrible business of inadvertently from time to time having to watch it. It is not only mothers who are appalled; it is every reasonable Australian. I think that point needs to be understood.

The legislation put into place by this Government has presumed that reasonable Australians do exist. The Government acknowledges that there are reasonable people, that there are people with community attitudes that are other than those of Senator Harradine and Senator Walters. It is not that all of us are madly into pornography, that we approve of it or that we rush around promoting it. Indeed, exactly the opposite is the case. We say in the legislation that we want to provide information about the classification of this material so that people can be in a position to make an informed choice. People should be given educational material, information and consumer protection so that they can make this choice. This Government promotes information and discussion. It promotes participation by people in the decisions which affect their lives. Where possible, it does not work by the heavy hand of censorship. As some honourable senators have already pointed out, the Government also appreciates that reasonable people's community standards would not tolerate the material that I mentioned earlier, the classification of which has been totally banned or which is not allowed entry to this country.

Following Senator Walters's arguments about censorship, the wrong evidence she quoted pointed to parents needing help; so I presume she would censor, for example, sweet biscuits and sugar to help parents protect their children's teeth rather than provide support, information, encouragement and education to help them help themselves by making informed choices, by relating with their children and by supervising what they eat. I think the analogy is rather good. I think that Senator Walters would prefer to ban things rather than to encourage people to make informed choices and to give them the support they need.

I have talked about the proposals being a matter of not recent concern but continuing concern. I certainly am aware that the Attorney-General, Mr Chris Summer, in my State of South Australia, has long addressed this problem. In fact , he was one of the early Attorneys-General to address himself of the matter. Therefore, South Australia is well placed to co-operate with the Federal legislation. In fact, I would say that if anything distinguishes the Labor Government from the Liberal Opposition and independents like Senator Harradine it is the way this Government has approached the question of dealing with that community concern. The legislation was amended as it was for reasons of providing information, of providing the classification, so that people can be in a position to make an informed choice. People cannot properly make choices if they do not know what is to hand. Senator Walters in her previous speech alluded to how people would have to ask the seller or the renter of the videotape: 'Is this all right for my family to watch?'. This is an entirely inappropriate decision for the sales person to have to make because presumably most sales people would not have watched the material and would not know what was in it.

I have referred previously to complaints that have been given to me by people who have hired or bought videotapes for family or children's viewing, particularly those who have hired them, and have found attached to the end of the tapes advertisement segments featuring pornographic films. As I recall, Senator Mason alluded to this in his speech earlier. It is for those reasons too -to guarantee that no such pornographic trailers could be attached to videotapes designed for family viewing-that the Government introduced its classification code. To suggest that classifying information or videotapes was a way of wildly rampaging through the community and encouraging the spread of pornography is, I think, a dangerous way of addressing the problem. I think that in some ways both Senator Harradine and Senator Walters could be described as destructively mischievous in their approach to this debate.

I wish to address another point that is of considerable concern to the women's movement. It is an issue to which I have alluded before and which I think is of continuing concern to feminists-I include under the word 'feminists' all women of concern and care and that is just about all of us. Those women are very concerned that the pornography films perpetuate stereotype roles for men and women, stereotyped expectations that women enjoy violence and stereotyped expectations that men enjoy doing it to people and watching it being done. I think that all of those are crassly insulting to the men and women in our society. It is not true of most of us. But the feminists have had to address this question in terms of whether or not a censorship approach is more appropriate than a classification one. I quote again the interesting comments that were made by women in America. I refer to an article which appeared in the National Times on 30 March 1984, which reads:

In the US, where the First Amendment to the Constitution guarantees free speech , the Women Against Pornography are more cognisant of the dangers of censorship than their Australian sisters. 'We do not advocate censorship. We respect the First Amendment stricture against imposition of prior restraint on any form of speech,' their leaflets state.
Feminists here--
meaning in America-
concede that banning pornography will not even begin to attack the reasons why so many men hate and oppose women. And they work on many other fronts to end sexism and violence against women.
Again, I think that that point needs to be stressed and I take this opportunity to stress it.

I think everybody in this place would be in general sympathy about pornography. We do not like it; we disapprove of it. But the difference is whether we ban it totally or classify it under the strict guidelines that have been proposed by the Government and allow people to make informed choices. We cannot use censorship to try to address the problem of changing society's attitudes that are sexist and deeply inbuilt in our community. I believe that either banning or classifying pornography is only one small part of the answer. I suggest that censorship is not the way to change attitudes at all because that denies people any knowledge from which they can develop their attitudes. But sexist attitudes in our society are not built in from pornography. They are built in from all sorts of things-from magazines and daily advertising on television, from things that we regard as not pornography at all. Perhaps the most pornographic feature of our society is the perpetual regarding of women as sex objects in advertisements, sales promotions and so on. I again commend the Government for its legislation in this area. I once again feel that it is a great shame that we have had to waste time rerunning this argument for the Senate this afternoon.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON CONSTITUTIONAL AND LEGAL AFFAIRS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I seek leave to make a short statement correcting an unfortunate error in the report of the Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs entitled 'Freedom of Information Act 1982-Annual Report by the Attorney-General on the operation of the act for the period 1 December 1982 to 30 June 1983'.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Committee's report was tabled in the Senate last Wednesday, 6 June. At paragraph 5.7 on page 10 of the report the following statement appears:

SPEECH.PARA: It is interesting, though, that six of the seven conclusive certificates granted by the Attorney-General have been for 'internal working documents'.

This sentence is incorrect in stating that conclusive certificates have been granted by the Attorney-General. In fact, the Attorney-General has granted no conclusive certificates under the Act and the seven conclusive certificates referred to were granted in one case by a Minister in the previous Government and, in the remaining six cases, by principal officers of agencies. It is a matter for regret that this error occurred in the Committee's report. The Committee is aware of the Attorney-General's personal view-I certainly am having served with him on the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs when it drew up its report on the freedom of information proposal-that the granting of a conclusive certificate under the relevant provisions of the Freedom of Information Act should be avoided if at all possible. The Committee hopes that he has not been unduly embarrassed by the error in our report.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN PARLIAMENTARY DELEGATION TO THE INTER-PARLIAMENTARY UNION CONFERENCE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-For the information of honourable senators I present the report of the Australian delegation to the seventy-first Inter- Parliamentary Union Conference held in Geneva, Switzerland, in April 1984, together with a document entitled 'Results of the 1984 Spring Session of the Inter-Parliamentary Union'.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a statement in connection with the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. The original venue for the seventy-first Inter-Parliamentary Union Conference was Jakarta, but because the Indonesian authorities were unable to accommodate the delegation from Israel it was necessary, under the rules, to seek an alternative centre. Reasons, including the shortage of time for preparation of the conference, the increasing cost to the host country, sensitivities because of security and other world pressures, caused many countries to be hesitant in offering to host the conference. Therefore, the organising committee arranged for the IPU Conference to be held at its headquarters in Switzerland. The atmosphere of the city of Geneva, a place steeped in history for peace and international co-operation, was such that Geneva was a most appropriate venue for delegates from the 102 member countries to meet. After all, Geneva is considered to be the humanitarian capital of the world. In Geneva there is a real sense of an international community. It is also a major international conference centre where many a country's foreign policy is on display, being a window to the world of both its domestic and foreign policies. Geneva is the headquarters for United Nations disaster relief, refugees, human rights, the International Red Cross, the International Court of Jurists, the World Council of Churches, the world centre of the International Labour Organisation, the World Health Organisation, world patents, trade, and many other international bodies. Switzerland, being a land locked country, has no unity of language and no binding ethnic origin. Yet despite its diversifying elements, it manages a cohesion within its 23 cantons-the sort of cohesion that the world is seeking to attain.

SPEECH.PARA: The IPU brings together parliamentarians representing different ideologies and countries for the objective study of political, economic, social, judicial and cultural problems of international significance. Its aims are to promote personal contact between members of all parliaments and to unite them in common action to secure and maintain the full participation of their respective states in the firm establishment and development of democratic institutions and in the advancement of the work of international peace and co-operation, particularly by supporting the work of the United Nations. Many speakers at the IPU Conference emphasised that isolated problems, capable in the past of resolution by unilateral action, nowadays require a global solution. Others warned that statesmen must not be blinded by their immediate interests. However, all agreed that the main challenge was the prevention of nuclear war.

The IPU is a very representative body and one of the very few world forums in which parliamentarians of a wide variety of political opinion can work to maintain the often divergent objectives of national sovereignty and international solidarity. It is to be hoped that on returning home delegates can adapt internationally inspired resolutions into national determinations. It is a regrettable fact that in this sophisticated twentieth century, with the growth in the technological power bases, the collective wisdom has not kept pace but has, in fact, tended to diminish. Nowadays world leaders tend to take notice of events, including imbalances in trade resources, war threats and destabilising population growth, without necessarily finding remedies. Unfortunately, throughout the world there is war, terrorism, abrogation of civil and political rights, torture and, because of the drought which is affecting 24 African countries, a major refugee problem. In too many countries population growth is leading to reduced living standards, particularly in developing countries. For the developed countries this means that recovery will not be as complete, as strong or as sustainable.

The admission of China and the re-admission of Argentina were met with widespread applause from the assembled delegates. Delegates appeared to acknowledge that the changes in the development of international technology will continue despite changes in the disposition of power. Such advances mean that, from a communication viewpoint, the world is effectively shrinking. That factor is probably less evident in Australia because of our isolation and distance to major centres. I believe it is essential for politicians to go overseas to witness and to debate at first hand the problems of a world in transition to enable a proper perspective of the structural changes taking place to be obtained by them and to be understood by Australians. I draw to the attention of the Senate five brief extracts from the debate to show to the Senate and the Australian community the concerns of their colleagues from other countries. The first is:
The world has defeated smallpox with a smaller budget than was necessary for the development of one super bomb.
From Venezuela:
Destiny of developing countries could not be left to the superpowers, nor even on regional co-operation; each country had to be responsible for itself and had to respect the opinion of others.
From Zambia:
To Africans, small arms were more dangerous than a nuclear weapon.
From Bolivia:
Bolivia had a heavy debt burden, which used up more than 40 per cent of its export income in repayments.

The Bolivian delegate said that he saw an indirect relationship between the program indebtedness of the developing countries and the arms expenditure of the big powers. The delegate from Sudan stated:

The rate of desert encroachment on fertile and arable land in Africa was between four and five kilometres per year. This relentless destruction of Africa 's resources must be stopped. Desertification threatened the loss of about 35 per cent of the world's arable land, half of which was located in Africa.

I take this opportunity through the airwaves of giving a cheerio to our leader, Ralph Jacobi. I regret that the leader of the Australian delegation was unable to present this report because of the time constraints of the other House. The Australian delegation to the Inter-Parliamentary Union Conference was again led by Ralph Jacobi from South Australia. In Geneva, as in Seoul and Helsinki, Mr Jacobi was a great fighter for justice and democratic principles in both the Ten Plus forums, the IPU executive and council and the open debate of the IPU. His knowledge of Middle East affairs was of such a high standard that it enabled delegates to reduce the gulf of divergent opinions in this very sensitive area. Therefore, it was not surprising that he obtained the respectful title from his colleagues both here and abroad of 'the fearless leader'.

Senator Cook's contribution benefited from the counselling of Australia's Ambassador for Disarmament, the sincere Richard Butler. He displayed a knowledge a cut above the average and a sincerity which was lacking in speeches by some other delegations in the debate on disarmament and arms control. Peter Coleman and Dr Klugman showed their courage in attacking a number of sacred cows that generated both applause and criticism. Dr Klugman's concluding remarks are worth repeating. He said that war and aggression go hand in hand with dictatorial regimes because only they can start them without having to justify them to their people.

The Clerk of the Senate, in his normal role at the Senate table, appears a sombre, humourless but sage mediator. However, as secretary of the delegation we found a different kind of person-a person full of wit, great energy and a dedication to supply the needs of the members with timely and relevant information. Evan Adermann, John Dyer and Foreign Affairs adviser Fred Peppinck all made significant contributions which all helped to enhance other countries' respect for Australia.

I also wish to acknowledge the help from Australia's Ambassador for Disarmament , Richard Butler, and an ex-Tasmanian, who is now Ambassador for Australia in Berne, Mr Hutton. Especially I would like to mention David Sadlier, our Ambassador in Geneva. No other Foreign Affairs official has done quite so much in our experience as David Sadlier who arranged for delegates to be fully briefed and informed. At times some of our Foreign Affairs officers tend to brush off politicians overseas and treat them as an unfortunate interruption to their other duties. But not so David Sadlier. For example, at one significant dinner party the guest list included many distinguished international people. It included the Deputy High Commissioner for Refugees, the Director of Operations for the International Red Cross, and so on. Also among the distinguished guests was Christine Elstob, the daughter of South Australian Labor Senator, Ron Elstob . The pride that she has in her father at this time is significant. When family unions are tending to lessen, the bonds between Christine and her parents are particularly strong.

I come back to David Sadlier. Maybe in his earlier career as an Inter- Parliamentary Union Foreign Affairs adviser he learned of the needs of foreign delegates. Indeed, as a window to the world, our diplomatic representation in the whole of Switzerland gives Australia high status in the international community.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Robertson Sen E.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Sibraa, I table further additional information received by Estimates Committee E and seek leave for it to be incorporated in the Hansard record of the Committee's proceedings.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 12 June, on motion by Senator Gietzelt:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This omnibus Bill, which refers to changes, in part, to the Distillation Act 1901 and the Spirits Act 1906, has particular relevance to my State of South Australia as it touches the area of brandy excise and the quality of brandy as well as the quality of wine. For that reason I have risen to discuss this matter on behalf of my colleague Senator Rae who, as the shadow Minister for Industry and Commerce, would otherwise do so. This legislation follows a detailed review of legislation relating to wine and spirits undertaken jointly by the Food Standards Committee of the National Health and Medical Research Council and Commonwealth government departments. The changes will bring both Acts into line with new National Heath and Medical Research Council standards for wine and spirits which have been adopted by State governments.

SPEECH.PARA: These matters have caused considerable concern within both the brandy and wine industry in South Australia in particular. The concern is based mainly on the speed with which the Government has moved to introduce these new standards. The Minister for Industry and Commerce, Senator Button, foreshadowed the legislation on 4 May 1984 in his news release No. 32. In that release he referred to changes in the definition of brandy and wine as well as foreshadowing changes to abolish the excise duty on wine made with added sugar. No timetable has been given for the enactment of that last change. We recognise that these changes have resulted from a consultative program conducted by the National Health and Medical Research Council which has involved all State governments and the industry. However, the fundamental concern of industry on this matter is the quality of the product. Quality, obviously, is absolutely vital to the continued viability of the brandy and wine industry. Australia does produce fine quality wines and brandies but needs to be able to continue that way in the future in order to ensure its viability and to continue its expansion, particularly on the overseas markets.

In the past a considerable number of matters have troubled the brandy industry in particular. I do not exclude the wine industry from that. However, we recall the activities of the Whitlam Government between 1972 and 1975. That Government reduced the differential between Australian and imported brandy by increasing the excise on brandy. The figures speak for themselves. In 1974 Australian brandy accounted for 29 per cent of the market whereas imported brandy accounted for 7 per cent. By 1983 Australian brandy had fallen to 19 per cent of the market while imported brandy had risen to 26 per cent. In other words, there was a total reversal of the position. That was as a direct result of the increase in excise. In effect, a very substantial and important industry in South Australia has been largely destroyed as a result of government activity.

In the 1983 Budget the Hawke Government levied a new wine tax through the excise legislation which was expected to produce some $13m by March 1984. That has produced less than $500,000. That has been raised at the cost of crippling the fortified wine industry. This has been exemplified in recent days by the announcement by Yalumba Wines that it will no longer make fortified wines, therefore giving away some of its great port industry. Names such as Galway Pipe will go by the board in future. Only in the last few days or so another winery in South Australia, Hoffman's wines of Tanunda, has also announced its intention to close its fortified wine section.

People engaged in the wine industry recognise the dangerous position into which the Government has thrust the industry and the hardship that has been caused, not so much to the wine makers or their employees but to the grape growers, the small block owners in the Riverland and other parts of South Australia, particularly in the Barossa Valley, who rely on the fortified spirit and wine industry for the sale of their surplus products. That has been the traditional way in which the industry has taken care of its surplus products over the years. By turning its surplus grapes into spirit it preserves it in a form that can be utilised for later production of brandy and fortified wines. In that way the industry has been able to maintain its stability without having to rely on government support by way of social security or otherwise when times are hard.

It is no doubt quite obvious that there is great concern in South Australia about the current position of the industry. That has been exemplified by a great deal of newspaper editorial comment and other matters that have been raised in the media in South Australia. Even the Government has given some acknowledgement to the nature of this problem. In the March edition of the Stock and Land newspaper, the Minister for Primary Industry, Mr Kerin, was reported as having said:
The wine decision was out of my control.
It sure was-
To some degree it is not a wine tax; it's an excise levy--
he should explain the difference to me-
which particularly affects the most vulnerable end of the wine industry. I think it was a wrong decision.

It certainly was a wrong decision and the people of South Australia understand just how wrong it was. About 7,300 growers and labourers are employed in those two industries in Australia. There are as well 5,600 employees in the distilling and winemaking industry. There is some misapprehension that the wine and brandy industry pays very little taxation. A lot of it, of course, goes to the State governments as distinct from the Federal Government and perhaps that is where some of the misapprehension comes in. But even by the 1982-83 estimates of brandy excise that was paid, an amount of $36.5m came into Federal coffers. The excise on grapes also raised another $6.2m. But the amounts paid to the State governments by way of liquor taxes reaped $62.1m, while it is estimated that sales tax on brandy will bring in $15.9m in the current financial year. All in all State and Federal governments reap some $120m a year from the wine and brandy industries. These matters should be brought home, as there is some kind of misapprehension and common view in the community that these industries do not pay their way in taxation.

Turning to the legislation that is before us, and the amendments to the Spirits Act, Mr Acting Deputy President, I draw your attention to the use of the term in the definition of brandy. The changes that have occurred by way of this amendment lead us to the conclusion that products other than wine made from fresh grapes will be used in the future manufacture of brandy and will be acceptable according to the health standards. That is the major point at issue in this legislation. I foreshadow that I intend to move an amendment during the committee stage which will seek to redefine brandy as a spirit which is distilled wholly from wine which is the fermented juice of fresh grapes, so as to make it quite clear that this product is derived from wine and is not adulterated by other products. It is a vital quality issue, as I have stated earlier.

The concern of the industry, which has been made quite clear, I believe, to the Government as well as to the Opposition, follows a meeting of the Australian Wine and Brandy Producers Association in Adelaide about a fortnight ago when this matter was raised. Certain views were put as to the amendments which I believe would be satisfying to the industry if they were carried in the form that I have mentioned. I ask the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs ( Senator Ryan) whether she would give us an undertaking that, with regard to the argument that I have raised here today, she would be able to take the matter forward on behalf of the Opposition to the National Health and Medical Research Council in order to see whether it is possible to re-think this position. I seek her assurance to that effect. I hope she may be able to satisfy us when she winds up the debate, otherwise I will be forced to move my amendments.

Some sections of the wine industry have also expressed concern about the definition of wine under changes to be made to the Distillation Act and, as well , the foreshadowing of changes to the Excise Tariff Act. It is felt that those changes may lead to the possibility of wine being made from dried grapes through the addition of water and sugar. While this may not seem a terribly important matter, I point out to the Senate that this is particularly important when we consider the quality of Australian wines and the desire of the industry to further develop its markets on the world scene. It is fairly clear that if Australian wine loses its reputation, which is very high in terms of quality, consequently our opportunities on world markets will diminish.

Other people in the industry have pointed out that State government provisions allow only for the addition of 3 per cent of water to wine. Concern about that matter is not so great, but it is also argued that the liberalisation of definitions will possibly allow greater use of technology in the methodology and production of wine. That is a matter of great concern. If one refers to wine in relation to fresh grapes, the term 'fresh grapes' would have to be defined. Some winemakers prune their vines and leave grapes hanging for some time before picking them. Would they be technically classed as fresh grapes? I believe we need to make that point clear. Mr Acting Deputy President, I believe you have heard enough from me on this matter. I know other senators wish to speak on this matter which is of very great concern to my State. I reiterate in conclusion that it is a matter of very great concern to the industry, as it is vital to the question of quality of our wine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will speak now rather than in the Committee stage since the item that I wish to raise is connected, at least tangentially, with that raised by Senator Messner. It is a point that I have raised every year for the last three years and hopefully some action might finally start to be taken on it. It does not concern a large industry; in fact, it concerns a very small, struggling industry-that is, the wines which are made from fruit other than grapes. The whole sorry episode goes back a long way. Wine made from grapes is, of course exempt from sales tax. Wine made from fruit other than grapes attracts at the moment sales tax of 20 per cent. It arises from an interpretation of the Commissioner of Taxation, who has taken it upon himself to declare that wines made from anything other than grapes are not wines, and certainly not Australian wines, despite the fact that the technology of wine making and every other reference book that one can find states:

SPEECH.PARA: 3. the juice, fermented or unfermented, of various other fruits or plants, used as a beverage, etc.: gooseberry wine . . .

Undoubtedly, wines made from fruits other than grapes are wines, are Australian wines, and are made by Australians who are attempting to develop an industry in this country, particularly in my State, from tropical fruits. While they are trying to establish an industry, the Government is trying to tax them out of existence. It will not touch wine made from grapes; but it will try to destroy people who are trying to make wines from any other fruit and trying to do so commercially.

This was first brought to the Government's attention in 1977 and intermittently thereafter. I took it up in 1980 and tried unsuccessfully through the Department of the Treasury to get a reply to my requests. I finally wrote to the then Treasurer. I received a letter from Senator Messner, who was then the Minister Assisting the Treasurer. He stated that the granting of a sales tax exemption had to be taken into account in the overall economic strategy. Since the total amount of money that had been made in the previous year was about $3,500, I assumed that the letter was a joke sent by somebody because it was around about April. I did not believe the entire economics of Australia were about to fall to the ground because we were not going to put sales tax on something that had created a $3,500 profit. So I tried again. This time my query must have gone to some other person in the Department or the Minister's office who also fancied himself as a practical joker, because this time the response was that it would destroy GATT. The General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade would collapse about our ears if we did something to assist this small, struggling Australian industry. I thought that that was a joke and I put it in the waste paper basket too.

I then decided on a different tack and that was to take it up in the debates on the amendments to the sales tax legislation. I will not go on with the story, but the next time I took up the matter was in 1982 and again in 1983. In 1983 Senator Walsh gave a totally different response which was even more confusing than the last one. He suggested that there was a valid case and that movement ought to be made towards a greater degree of tax neutrality than presently existed. I thought that we would get somewhere, but he then said the Government was not going to do anything about it. That brings us again to 1984. I expect that the next chance I will have to raise this will be during the Budget session when, in fact, I do intend to raise it if I cannot get any assurances that this particular problem will be considered with some sympathy and genuine understanding. A small group of people are being driven out of what could be a very useful business. There are only about three of these wineries established around Australia. Only one winery producing commercially from tropical fruits operates in my State. I understand that one winery in New South Wales produces from other fruits and one produces mead from honey. Those wineries are all in the same position.

In every case those commercial wineries are a tourist attraction. The one in Queensland, for example, is in Bundaberg. It is set up as a tourist attraction. It is attempting to operate as part of the tourist sector in Bundaberg. I would have thought that the Government's new-found interest in tourism might also have led it to think that these wineries might be considered useful tourist attractions. The Government's rhetoric in relation to small business might also lead it to look at this, because this is small business. Almost inevitably, only one or two people are involved in these wineries, yet they are paying 20 per cent sales tax when all other wineries are not paying any tax at all. Surely this is a matter of discrimination against a few small people. The world will not stop if nothing happens about this, but I can assure the Senate that those businesses will go out of business. They are just scraping by now. They are hoping that some sanity may appear on the horizon to rescue them and to assist them to make at least some profit in what could be a useful trade and a useful developing industry for Australia, particularly given our wide range of tropical fruits. I hope that the Minister may be more sympathetic than the Ministers to whom I have previously addressed this problem. It might give at least a glimmer of hope to the small business people if they believe they can make a living out of this.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak on the Statute Law ( Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill and refer to the provisions on page 28 of the Schedule to that Bill. They involve an amendment to section 44 of the Family Law Act. The amendment clarifies the responsibility of an appropriate officer of a Family Court of a State in respect of required reconciliation counselling for marriages, where the application for dissolution of the marriage is filed within the period of two years after the date of the marriage. Under section 44 of the principal Act, in that case the application shall not be filed unless it is accompanied by a certificate in the prescribed form-

SPEECH.PARA: (a) stating that the parties to the marriage have considered a reconciliation, with the assistance of a specified person or organization, being-
(i) a marriage counsellor or an approved marriage counselling organization;
(ii) another suitable person or organization nominated by the Principal Director of Court Counselling of the Family Court; or
(iii) an appropriate officer of a Family Court of a State; and
(b) signed by that person or on behalf of that organization, as the case may be .

There has been some question as to whether the appropriate officer of a Family Court of a State could refer for counselling those partners to the marriage to a marriage counsellor or an approved marriage counselling organisation or some other suitable person, or whether it had to be done by an appropriate officer of the Family Court. This amendment to the statute law clarifies that situation and enables the appropriate officer of the Family Court of a State to appoint another suitable person or organisation to nominate another suitable person or organisation to perform the counselling service. As such, I think it is an appropriate clarification of what was intended in that section when the matter was discussed in October 1983.

Court counsellors in the Federal registries are at present overloaded. Incidentally, those court counsellors-I would think the Attorney-General ( Senator Gareth Evans) could correct me if I am wrong-are mainly engaged in separation counselling rather than reconciliation counselling. By and large, they counsel on matters of custody, access and division of property. A degree of opportunity is there for reconciliation counselling, but because of the substantial number of divorce applications, which place a burden on the Family Court, the counsellors are very much overloaded. We should examine that situation and enable counsellors to engage more in reconciliation counselling which would, of course, prevent the need for separation counselling.

The recent annual report of the Institute of Family Studies has described clearly the devastating fact facing Australian society today, namely, that 40 per cent of marriages entered into will end up in divorce. That is a devastating statistic, one of which we as a society and as a parliament can hardly be proud. It is my view and that of very many people that the law has an educative role. Amendments that have been made to family law legislation-indeed, the Family Law Act itself, initially-have had an educative role to the detriment of society. I believe it is fairly generally recognised that people do not truly accept the obligations willingly entered into upon marriage. A covenant made between two people can be disregarded almost at will after 12 months' separation. That is the only ground. Of course, great concern and distress are felt by the partners to the marriage in those circumstances. Any law which is increasingly not founded upon the consensus of the whole of the community is destined not to be observed. We have a number of manifestations of that, in that persons have expressed their disenchantment with the Family Law Act in ways which are not acceptable to society and cannot be condoned in any shape or form. But again, in my view, we as a parliament must at some stage have a really good look at the family law legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Spare us that now.
—I would be out of order if I dealt with that at length now. I want to get at the particular point that is made, which widens the scope-
—It does not even do that; it just restores it. It was an inadvertent omission. You have had a pretty long string so far.

—I am drawing a long bow. But it restores the situation with regard to the persons who are able to provide counselling. I remind the Senate that not only are there costs involved to the individuals concerned but there are great costs to the community involved in the dissolution of marriage. Just to update the figures, I should like to mention that the figures that have been provided to me show that 68.6 per cent of those receiving the supporting parent' s benefit, at a cost in 1982-83 of $727.7m, are separated wives or de facto wives.

—On a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President. I hate to interrupt Senator Harradine, because he is dealing with an important matter; however, it really is stretching an extremely long bow to diverge, as he is doing, on to these matters, with what is essentially an amendment of very narrow scope, a very technical amendment, which is doing no more than reinstating the status quo. It is not a policy matter that is before us now. I suggest that Senator Harradine be asked to confine himself to the particular matter before the Senate.
—Senator Harradine, you have been straying a little wide of the Bill. I ask you to return to the Bill and to remain relevant to it.

—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. I acknowledge the point of order and I accept your ruling. I hope that the Attorney-General will, at some future stage, give consideration again to my proposal in relation to the need for required reconciliation counselling for the purpose of getting the partners to the marriage together to consider the legal, social and financial consequences of the dissolution of marriage and, in particular, the effect of that dissolution of the marriage on any children of the marriage and, having regard to the consequences and effect referred to, the possibility of reconciliation. I acknowledge that, as a result of the debate that we had, the Minister gave an undertaking to expend a certain amount of money in an advertising campaign. I see that that campaign has now been launched. I endorse that and I congratulate the Minister on that, if the Standing Orders will allow me to do so. I hope that this will be continued and that when the Minister is preparing his bids for the Budget he will look at the amount of money available for pre-marriage counselling as well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This piece of legislation amends some 51 Acts covering almost the whole legislative universe which allows honourable senators to range pretty widely in what they talk about. I express my gratitude to the 61 honourable senators who exercised self- restraint and did not speak on this piece of legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn now to the matters raised by Senator Messner. He has foreshadowed amendments to the definition of brandy, which he will move in the Committee stage. Perhaps I can anticipate that motion and reply to it now, without the need for further debate. These amendments relate to the representations made, essentially at the eleventh hour, by the Australian Wine and Brandy Producers Association. They were raised in the House of Representatives by Mr Andrew. A full answer was given by Mr Duffy, the relevant Minister in charge of the Bill concerned, on 4 June-as reported in Hansard at pages 2835 to 2838. I shall not reply in repetition of that here now. It is a little curious, perhaps, that these representations were left until the last minute when the definition was, after all, part of a standard adopted by the National Health and Medical Research Council in 1983, after several years of discussion and examination. However, the Government recognises, of course, the importance of a successful and viable Australian grape and brandy industry. I am certainly prepared, on behalf of the Government, to give the undertaking sought by Senator Messner; namely, that representations and the foreshadowed amendment will be referred to the NHMRC for study and report. I do that after consultations with the relevant section of the Department of Industry and Commerce, so I say with some confidence that that will be attended to in the way sought.

As to the matter raised by Senator Macklin, it was, essentially, to similar effect. The States and the Commonwealth are implementing definitions on a wide cross-section of legislation. In relation to the definition of wine, which was the subject, as I understand it, of Senator Macklin's contribution and proposed Committee stage amendment, I again undertake, on behalf of the Government, to ensure that that question is referred to the NHMRC for study and advice. I hope, accordingly, that it will not become necessary for Senator Macklin to carry out in the Budget session the course of activity that he mentioned, and that the matter will be attended to to his satisfaction.

As to the matters raised by Senator Harradine, he was speaking to a provision in this miscellaneous amendments Bill which, as I said by way of a point of order earlier, simply reinstated in its appropriate place a provision concerning the machinery of counselling which had been inadvertently omitted in the revisions of the legislation which took place last year. But Senator Harradine took the opportunity to express views about the role, significance and utility of counselling, and particularly reconciliation counselling, which I fully endorse. I only wish that the resources were available in the family law courts to make possible the provision of that counselling on the scale that we would all like.

I am glad that Senator Harradine referred to the $100,000 campaign that is now being set in train to draw the community's attention to the services in this respect provided by the marriage counselling organisations and the private sector organisations. I also draw his attention to the proposal, which I hope to be able to get moving this year, for family law centres attached to, or in vicinity of, certain of the family law courts in various areas, whose primary function will be that of mediation and, in anticipation of family law disputes, to try to get people back together again and stop matters which might otherwise get to court and occupy court time. It is, again, a variation on the counselling theme-not just in the context of after-the-event division of the spoils or division of custody of children; it is a matter of trying to anticipate and head off those problems arising in the first place, and to get people back together again as far as is humanly possible, rather than just clean up the wreckage afterwards. I fully endorse the sentiments expressed by Senator Harradine. I shall continue to bear actively in mind the sentiments that he has expressed during the--

TALK.START.PARA: —Will you give us an opportunity to have an input about those family law centres? There are a couple of problems about them.

—I shall be happy to do that. They are only in a very early stage of formulation. The particular concept will depend on my being able to get some resources out of the current Budget. If Senator Harradine will allow me to sit down and conclude the debate I will be off to see Mr Dawkins in a matter of two or three minutes in order to do just that. With those remarks, I commend the Bill to the Senate and wish the Bill a speedy passage.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

DEBATE.TITLE: TAXATION (UNPAID COMPANY TAX) ASSESSMENT AMENDMENT BILL 1983 (No. 2) [No. 2]( 1984)

PROCTEXT.PARA: [COGNATE BILL:
DIVIDEND RECOUPMENT TAX BILL 1983 [No. 2] (1984)]
Debate resumed from 10 May, on motion by Senator Walsh:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Amendment Bill 1983 (No. 2) [No. 2] 1984 and the Dividend Recoupment Tax Bill 1983 [No. 2] are re-presented to us, having initially been presented by the Government on Budget night 1983. It is claimed that these Bills are identical to the Bills presented previously. It is also claimed that the Bills amend the unpaid company tax recoupment law to extend the scope of the legislation so that personal tax avoided by former owners of companies stripped of pre-tax profits will be subject to recoupment in relation to revenue profits in the years in respect of which company tax was evaded. They will also, as is described, ensure that liability for recoupment tax will not be escaped by reason of an ultimately unsuccessful post-sale or pre-sale tax avoidance scheme. The Bills authorise the Commissioner of Taxation to do a number of other things, as they did on their first introduction.

SPEECH.PARA: As far as the Opposition is concerned it stated its opposition to these Bills the first time they were presented, as it did to the Bills introduced by the Government claiming recoupment of tax on other occasions. We have to ask why this Bill is the one re-presented to us and why not the Dawkins Bill, that was the Government's first introduction of tax avoidance legislation.

I think what ought to be said at the time of dealing with these Bills tonight is that tax avoidance in Australia is a dead issue but an issue which the present Government wants to keep alive. The Fraser Government, after years of determined and consistent action and legislation in this area, laid the tax avoidance industry in its grave. That is the conclusion of all recognised experts in the taxation field and even in a rare moment of honesty, of the Federal Minister for Finance, Mr John Dawkins. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), in his own desperate search for some sort of election issue, is trying to deny the coalition's unparalleled record in smashing the tax avoidance industry.

The Australian Labor Party myth machine, having manufactured the claim that the Fraser Government lacked the resolve to tackle tax avoidance head on, is now cultivating the lie that the Liberal and National parties are friends of the tax cheats. Those are the terms used by the Prime Minister when speaking to his own Labor Party faithful in Adelaide shortly before Easter. He said at that time that the Liberals and the Nationals and the Australian Democrats will not be able to move away from the fact that they are the friends of the tax cheats in Australia. He said: 'They will be labelled as the people who have cost Australians half a billion dollars by their refusal on three occasions to pass through the Senate legislation dealing with unpaid tax'. It will be well known through the debates held in the Senate, at least, that the truth of the matter is that the Fraser Government, in a campaign against tax avoidance waged over five years, effectively closed down the tax avoidance industry in this country.

The Labor Government, in its desperate attempt to breath life back into the decaying corpse of the tax avoidance bogy, has resorted to insidious retrospective legislation to deal with practices and schemes which have already been wiped out as a result of the legislation of the Fraser Government. Labor is simply trying to manufacture a phoney issue for electoral purposes. The nature of Mr Hawke's campaign, particularly the language that he has used with regard to this matter, sits very uneasily with the admission of his own Minister for Finance, Mr Dawkins, who told a meeting of chartered accountants in Sydney on 14 April that tax avoidance in Australia was 'dead as an issue'. That is the impression and the understanding of the experts, the professionals, and those who deal with tax legislation in any depth.

I take this opportunity at this time when we are dealing with Bills re- presented to us to state something of the record of action of the Liberal Party when in government and the way in which we quite unashamedly dealt with the tax avoidance industry over a number of years. I recall that it was early in 1978 that the Fraser Government waged a war of exposure and legislation against the tax avoiders and eventually closed down this industry which had grown and expanded under the Whitlam Government and which had received encouragement from several High Court of Australia decisions. Even the present Treasurer, Mr Paul Keating, has admitted that the tax avoidance industry sprang into life during the days of the Whitlam Government. He stated on a 4BC talk back program in September 1982:
When we were in government between '73 and '75 the tax avoidance industry started to move into sophisticated contrived schemes. Schemes that were artificial devices to avoid tax.

It is fair to recall that decisions of the High Court during the 1970s, especially the 1974 decision on the Curran-type tax avoidance schemes and the 1977 judgments in Slutzkin's case and Cridland's case, effectively destroyed the anti-avoidance provisions of the Income Tax Assessment Act. Those decisions eroded the standards of conduct in the community generally on tax liabilities. That was understood by the Fraser Government when in office. It signalled the start of its fight against tax avoidance in the 1977 Budget Speech when the then Treasurer, Phillip Lynch, said:

The Government is well aware of the activities of tax planners who, increasingly, are promoting tax avoidance schemes and arrangements throughout the business and professional community. We propose to crack down hard on such practices.

From early 1978 onwards the Fraser Government followed a steady pattern of outlawing specific tax avoidance practices as they came to light. A string of amendments to taxation laws were announced and subsequently implemented. By the start of 1982 the Fraser Government had introduced over 22 pieces of legislation closing down over 50 tax avoidance schemes. That sits very uneasily with the Prime Minister's assertion that the Liberal Party and the National Party-he also singled out the Democrats in this place-are the friends of the tax cheats. That is the record-all of those pieces of legislation to deal with contrived schemes to ensure that the proper tax was paid by those receiving income and making profits from their corporate ventures.

The two landmark pieces of legislation in this area were the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act, passed in December 1980, which prospectively created a criminal offence for bottom of the harbour transactions, and the new Part IVA of the Income Tax Assessment Act which was a general anti-avoidance provision replacing section 260 which had lost favour with the High Court. The new Part IVA came into operation in May 1981. Tax avoidance became a topic of major public debate in 1982 after the release of two reports-the McCabe-Lafranchi report commissioned by the former Liberal Government in Victoria, which detailed the activities of promoters of bottom of the harbour schemes before these were blocked by the introduction of the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act in 1980, and the Costigan report of the Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union, which exposed bureaucratic delays and improper behaviour within the Public Service in tackling this problem.

However, the total tax avoided in the bottom of the harbour schemes of about $ 500m was relatively small compared with the enormous amount saved by the Fraser Government's massive anti-avoidance legislation which was needed to arrest the growth of the tax avoidance industry, mainly resulting from High Court of Australia decisions unfavourable to the Commissioner of Taxation. In a table in September 1982 the Commissioner of Taxation gave particulars of deduction claims involving tax avoidance for the years 1974-75 to 1980-81. That showed the extent of the claims, starting with $1.2m in the first year of 1974, $47.9m in the next year, $151.9m in the following year, through to $1,859m in 1977-78, diminishing in 1978 to $400m, in 1979 to $400m and 1980-81 to $122m. The Commissioner of Taxation believes that he will successfully collect all of those sums that were in the table that he released.

However, the bottom of the harbour schemes received more public notoriety than the successful fight against avoidance because of the fraudulent conduct of some of those involved, and the colourful and sensational treatment of the issue in the McCabe-Lafranchi and Costigan reports. When these reports were received the Fraser Government quickly and decisively framed legislation to empower the Australian Taxation Office to recoup the taxes evaded through these schemes from 1972 to 1980. That package of legislation, centred on the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Act, was passed in the Parliament in late 1982.

This is the point that has to be made in dealing with these retrospective tax Bills that are before us tonight. Although that legislation had a retrospective element in it, it did not create a new tax liability. It was designed to recover a tax liability which had always existed by shifting responsibility for that tax from defunct companies without assets to pay the tax to former owners of the companies who had financially benefited from the non-payment of the tax. This was a vastly different approach from the Hawke Government's legislation, which retrospectively creates a totally new taxation liability. That is the point that needs to be made. The Fraser Government's legislation was recoupment of tax. It recouped tax that had been unpaid. The legislation that is before us today creates a new liability and applies it retrospectively. That is the reason why, when these Bills were presented to us previously, we said that we were unable to support them. We cannot support retrospective legislation creating a new liability, in some cases on people who did not even exist as shareholders at that time. The Prime Minister said that this is to be an election issue and that he would hound the members of the Opposition again and again as being friends of the tax cheats. We ought to have an explanation from him of how one can place that sort of a tag on people who refuse to deal with retrospective legislation which creates a new liability.

The Commissioner of Taxation has made many comments with regard to the position of his requirement for anti-avoidance legislation. He advised the Fraser Government that legislation had wiped out tax avoidance in Australia. On 3 March 1983, only days before the change of government, the Commissioner sent a detailed letter to the then Treasurer, Mr Howard, assessing the tax avoidance minimisation issue in the wake of the recoupment legislation. That letter from the Taxation Commissioner to Mr Howard stated:

The evidence available to this office suggests that the introduction on 27 May 1981 of Part IVA (of the Taxation Act) with effect from that date effectively put a stop to the promotion of new tax avoidance schemes of a blatant, artificial or contrived nature.
When tabling this letter in the Parliament in March 1984, Mr Howard said:
There could be no more telling judgment on the quality and effectiveness of the action taken by the last Government on that issue than that judgment of the Commissioner of Taxation.

The Commissioner had said that it had been effectively blocked out. It seems to me that the Hawke Labor Government is searching for some issue. But it should also search for some credibility on some of the statements that it has made, particularly the statements it made prior to being elected to government.

In August of 1982 the Labor Party released its policy on tax avoidance and called it 'A Fairer Taxation System'. This promised a tough, uncompromising stance against tax avoidance and evasion. No one would argue about that, if the Government could find some schemes against which it had to act. At that time Labor estimated that losses from tax avoidance and evasion were well in excess of $6 billion a year. It kept quoting that figure and terrifying the Australian people with it. During the election campaign of 1983 Mr Hawke pledged that he would wipe out the tax evasion and avoidance industry and the loss of untold millions of dollars. That was part of his policy speech. After the election, the new Minister for Finance, Mr John Dawkins, continued this myth of the lost millions when he announced:

. . . the Government will, as necessary, employ retrospective legislation to ensure tax sought to be avoided under any blatant tax avoidance scheme that comes to light during our term of office will be collected, irrespective of when the scheme was entered into.

That was what he said. It was when Mr Dawkins was in charge of taxation for the Government that he introduced the first Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Amendment Bill. It was a very cynical attempt to keep tax avoidance alive as an issue because it went back to areas already covered by the former Government's actions. It invented new cases of illusory avoidance and retrospectively created new taxation liabilities which had never previously existed. We rejected that first Bill that Mr Dawkins brought in as Minister for Finance. In that Bill he went much further than the Government has gone in any of the subsequent Bills which it has introduced. In fact we heard very little about the Bill after it was rejected because the Cabinet did not understand the provisions of the Bill, was not prepared to support it and was not prepared to talk about it after it had been rejected by the Senate. It was insidious; it was draconian; it was legislation aimed retrospectively to impose penal additional tax on schemes which had already been blocked by the Fraser Government's legislation. It contained penalty rates of about 1,000 per cent in some cases. It was retrospective legislation which would have cost some 26,000 people their jobs and probably closed down their businesses by confiscating their working capital.

That legislation of Mr Dawkins amounted more to an introduction of a capital gains tax, or perhaps even a wealth tax, because it sought to tax not only notional dividends but also capital profits and reserves which, if the company had been wound up lawfully, would not have been taxed at the time. The Dawkins Bill could be described only as one which introduced a capital gains tax. Perhaps that is why we have not heard any more about it from the Hawke Labor Government, particularly prior to the next election. That Bill disappeared. We had another couple of attempts to introduce legislation, but retrospective legislation creating new liabilities.

The Bill before us creates liabilities that did not previously exist. It creates liabilities which ignore provisions that exist in the Income Tax Assessment Act. It ignores completely the provisions that exist with regard to retention allowances and the fact that ordinary companies are not required each year to dispose of all their after tax profits to the owners of the company. It deems that these have been distributed. It imposes retrospectively a tax on them .

I think that I need say no more about the Bills before us than simply to assert again that members of the Liberal Party of Australia and the National Party of Australia will not pass legislation that imposes new taxes retrospectively and which is misleading in the description of the Bills and the measures that are put before us. It is extremely misleading to talk of recouping tax as if it were tax that had been due and had not been collected when really the Bill will create a new tax. The Bill ignores the provisions of the Income Tax Assessment Act and ignores completely the fact that there is such a thing as sufficient distribution. Even if the Bill were to require the payment of tax it could not do so under the present Income Tax Assessment Act. So, on behalf of the Opposition, I strenuously assert once again that we will reject the retrospective legislation before us. We abhor the fact that it will create a new liability and apply it retrospectively, ignoring the provisions of the Income Tax Assessment Act, and that it will serve as the election issue with which the Prime Minister wishes to confuse the Australian people.

I mentioned the consistent program of legislation that was introduced by the Liberal-National Party Government over five years which every professional and the Minister for Finance acknowledge has closed down the tax avoidance industry. The Fraser Government's recoupment legislation will collect over $500m. That legislation has been acknowledged by the Commissioner of Taxation to be working satisfactorily. The money will be recovered from the so-called bottom of the harbour schemes. The Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act and Part IVA of the Income Tax Assessment Act have effectively wiped out tax avoidance. For the present Minister of Finance to acknowledge that the tax avoidance industry is dead when speaking to a professional body, surely leaves Mr Hawke without the election issue that he wishes to use, in his own words, to 'hound the members of the Opposition as being friends of the tax cheats'. There is only one reason why Mr Hawke would try to fight the election on this contrived and manufactured issue; that is, he wishes to divert the attention of the Australian people from the real election issues-the economic problems, the level of taxation which individuals will have to pay, the cost of Medicare, the assault on the elderly through the assets test, the lump sum superannuation legislation which has passed through this place and all the other things that have affected the living standards of Australians. It sits very uneasily on Mr Hawke to describe this legislation as legislation which will solve the problems of the Australian community by creating an artificial and retrospective tax law to be applied to people who, under existing law, would not have been required to pay in the manner this legislation prescribes. So, on behalf of the Opposition, I indicate our total opposition to and rejection of these Bills.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-Listening to Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle's glowing account of the alleged anti-tax evasion and avoidance record of the Fraser Government has reminded me of a Stalinist rewrite of history. According to Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle, the Fraser Government waged an unremitting campaign against taxation avoidance and evasion. Let us try to reconcile that with the facts. So far as the bottom of the harbour schemes are concerned, the fact is that for years the former Treasurer, Mr Howard, received increasingly desperate entreaties from the Commissioner of Taxation to take action against those schemes because of the enormous leakage of corporate tax and other taxation revenue that the Commissioner had identified or believed existed. The reaction of the Fraser Government as far as the Treasurer was concerned was to do absolutely nothing until the scandals were fully exposed in the McCabe-Lafranchi report and one of the reports of the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union. Only then, only after their exposure through completely independent bodies and because of the former Prime Minister's intention to have a quick election, did the Fraser Government move to take action against the perpetrators of the bottom of the harbour frauds. I note that even Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle has acknowledged that the conduct of some of the people involved in those schemes was fraudulent.

SPEECH.PARA: So far as the former Attorney-General was concerned, he presided over the notorious five-year bottom of the drawer case. He sat on his hands for five years while his Department took no action whatsoever under the existing law which some people in the investigative branch of the Australian Taxation Office believed could have been used against the bottom of the harbour schemes. So on the one hand we had an Attorney-General who did nothing for five years and, on the other, a Treasurer who did nothing in response to the desperate entreaties of the Commissioner of Taxation which continued for more than two years. Finally , after those scandals had been publicly exposed by independent sources, the Fraser Government, facing a desperate election, decided to take action. That is a fact.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not intend to delay the passage of these Bills any further. Before the suspension of the sitting for dinner I responded briefly to Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle's apologia for five years of inertia. I think the fate of these Bills is fairly well known. Half of the members of the Senate will again, as they have done on previous occasions, prevent the Government from recovering hundreds of millions of dollars in taxation which ought to be paid. No further comment or debate, no matter how compelling or how rational, will make any difference to the way in which the members of the Senate will vote; they will vote the same way as they have before. Therefore, I suggest that the vote on the second reading be taken, Mr President.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

DEBATE.TITLE: ABORIGINAL AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDER HERITAGE (INTERIM PROTECTION) BILL 1984

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 6 June, on motion by Senator Ryan:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition will oppose the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage (Interim Protection) Bill. Our major objection is that this ill-considered and dangerous legislation does not primarily relate to sacred site protection but has much broader application. We believe that land rights are being pushed in this Bill at the expense of civil liberties and to the detriment of the individual rights of all Australians, both Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal. Not only will this Bill erode the goodwill built up by the positive initiatives of the previous Government but also it will erode the broad bipartisan approach favoured by all Australians towards the justifiable needs of Australia's Aboriginal people. The Government is antagonising otherwise sympathetic Australians with the production of this confrontationist Bill.
